channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: India’s economic reforms: Domestic resilience to reshape global standing
item.description: Labour codes, tax cuts and GST reforms position India for a new era of growth and international influence.

item.title: Sabah voters reject major parties in state election
item.description: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim faces voter backlash after appealing parts of a High Court ruling against the federal government.

item.title: Vietnam’s second Doi Moi: Growth, bottlenecks, and a role for Australia
item.description: Vietnam has announced a new round of sweeping reforms to propel the nation to high-income status. But long-term boldness is meeting short-term inertia.

item.title: Albanese Denounces ‘Antisemitic Terrorism’ in Bondi Beach Mass Shooting
item.description: Australia has vowed to tighten gun laws to combat rising antisemitism.

item.title: The plan to rescue Denmark’s weight-loss pioneer
item.description: To recover its lead in obesity drugs, Novo Nordisk is transforming itself

item.title: Does the Road to Disarming Hamas Lead Through Qatar and Turkey?
item.description: Diplomats and experts say Doha and Ankara have leverage, but it may not be enough.

item.title: Crypto’s real threat to banks
item.description: The industry is supplanting Wall Street’s privileged position on the American right

item.title: The War Room newsletter: What the Bondi Beach attack tells us
item.description: Shashank Joshi, our defence editor, reflects on a surge in antisemitism

item.title: Congress Is Recommitting to Resilience
item.description: But the NDAA can only do so much when the president won’t help.

item.title: An oil boom where the Amazon meets the Atlantic
item.description: Despite is green bona fides, Brazil cannot resist a second run at oil riches

item.title: Five Structural Trends Transforming the Global Economy
item.description: Amid rising instability, powerful demographic, technological, and financial forces are steering the global economy toward greater uncertainty. The best-prepared decision-makers will be those who recognize the stakes early and adjust accordingly.

item.title: The Time for Indo-Pacific Unity Has Come
item.description: The Indo-Pacific lacks many of the institutions and alliances that are now teetering elsewhere. But as instability proliferates worldwide, they are urgently needed, and the region's leaders should commit to realizing the late Japanese Prime Minister Abe Shinzō’s vision of an Indo-Pacific that is open, united, stable, and secure.

item.title: Why has the border between the Koreas fallen silent?
item.description: South Korea’s president wants to reduce tensions with the North

item.title: Leveraging Taiwan: India’s strategic counterbalance to China
item.description: Record trade and closer ties with Taipei mark New Delhi’s shift from caution to assertiveness.

item.title: Beware of Trump’s Global Broligarchy
item.description: The president’s pay-to-play mentality is undermining U.S. foreign policy.

item.title: Europe Should Stand with Japan on Taiwan
item.description: Just as Russian President Vladimir Putin was clear about his intentions toward Ukraine, Chinese President Xi Jinping has left no doubt about his plans for Taiwan. The only way to deter him from pursuing "reunification" with the island is to make clear that the costs of doing so will be punishing.

item.title: Trump’s Business Model Is to Break Europe
item.description: Washington wants a free hand for Silicon Valley and Russia investment. The EU is an obstacle—and the far right is an ally.

item.title: Bondi Shooting: Could Australia’s Worst Terrorist Attack on Home Soil Have Been Prevented?
item.description: After the deadly attack on a Hanukkah celebration, accusations arose that not enough has been done to protect Jewish Australians from a clear rise in antisemitism.

item.title: Honduras’ Electoral Breakdown Has Deep Implications for China and Taiwan
item.description: The failure to declare a winner – when both top contenders had advocated for dropping relations with Beijing – is reopening the geopolitical map of Central America.

item.title: Deporting American Democracy
item.description: The instability caused by the Nazis' mass deportations and Kristallnacht in the autumn of 1938 was unpopular in Germany – much as ICE raids are unpopular in US cities. For the Nazis, the radical next steps were possible only under cover of war – which may be true for US President Donald Trump as well.

item.title: What the Disappearance of the ‘One China’ Policy From Trump’s 2025 NSS Means for Taiwan
item.description: Is Washington moving away from the formula that has governed the tenuous Taiwan Strait equilibrium for 50 years?

item.title: China’s Fiscal Winter Is Freezing Out Local Businesses
item.description: As local officials scour every corner for cash, businesses are taking the hit – in unpaid contracts.

item.title: The Death—and Rebirth—of Science Diplomacy
item.description: Once a vehicle for global cooperation, international science has become a high-stakes arena of geopolitical rivalry.

item.title: US Weapons Left Behind in Afghanistan Are Fueling Militancy in Pakistan
item.description: Taliban officials admit that at least half of the stockpile is now "unaccounted for.” Many of those weapons ended up with militant groups operating across Afghanistan’s borders.

item.title: What Trump’s New National Security Strategy Means for India
item.description: It divides the world into spheres of influence, with one for the U.S. in the Western Hemisphere and one for China in Asia.

item.title: Italy’s Gold Gambit
item.description: By proclaiming that Italy's official gold reserves – the world's third largest – belong to "the Italian people," Giorgia Meloni's government is essentially highlighting its contingency plan for a major crisis. At a time of declining confidence in European institutions, that is the last thing the eurozone needs.

item.title: Iran Has a New Moral Order
item.description: The Islamic republic no longer controls the symbolic universe that once anchored its legitimacy.

item.title: What Chile’s New President Means for the World
item.description: José Kast’s right-wing agenda has implications far beyond Chile’s borders.

item.title: Essential India newsletter: Where in the world is Leo Mirani?
item.description: Our Asia correspondent explains why most Asian megacities fail

item.title: How to Keep Nigeria’s Schoolchildren Safe
item.description: Too many Nigerian students have had their education interrupted by terrorism and kidnapping for ransom. If parents are to allow their children to return to school in the new year, adequate security infrastructure, clear communication protocols, and effective early-warning systems will be needed.

item.title: The Sabah Duopoly and the Autonomy Ultimatum in East Malaysia
item.description: Peninsular-origin parties suffered a catastrophic rejection in the late November polls, while a local duopoly emerged in East Malaysia.

item.title: Meeting the challenge of violent extremism
item.description: ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess' words at the Lowy Lecture in November now carry new significance.

item.title: What we know about the Bondi attack
item.description: There is a clear need to invest more in the prevention of extremism and violence.

item.title: Are the Drug Boat Killings Trump’s Vietnam Moment?
item.description: One senator’s investigation into Lyndon Johnson’s expanding war was a turning point.

item.title: What Trump’s National Security Strategy Gets Right
item.description: Despite the bombastic rhetoric, America Isn’t retreating.

item.title: The Needless Rift Between America and Colombia
item.description: How to rescue Washington’s most important partnership in Latin America.

item.title: America’s Drone Delusion
item.description: Why the lessons of Ukraine don’t apply to a conflict with China.

item.title: Dictators Don’t Take Holidays
item.description: Myanmar's generals are counting on Western governments overlooking the sham election that they have scheduled for December 28.

item.title: Philippines Claims Three Fishermen Injured in Skirmish With Chinese Coast Guard
item.description: Manila claims that around 20 fishing boats were hit with “water cannons and dangerous blocking maneuvers” close to Sabina Shoal in the South China Sea.

item.title: Thailand-Cambodia Fighting Enters Second Week as Bangkok Spurns Attempts at Outside Mediation
item.description: The Royal Thai Army says there will be no ceasefire “until Cambodia ceases its hostilities and attacks against Thai troops and civilians in the border area."

item.title: Will the Fed Be Allowed to Do Its Job?
item.description: Less than one year into his second term, Donald Trump has already begun to undermine the US Federal Reserve’s independence, introducing risks unseen since the 1970s. For the sake of the global economy, we should all hope that the next chair still has the space – and the resolve – to serve the public interest.

item.title: China and America Must Get Serious About AI Risk
item.description: China and America will continue to compete vigorously for the lead in AI. But as the world’s two – and only – AI superpowers, both countries urgently need to engage one another directly to address the growing list of dangers that the technology poses to markets, infrastructure, social stability, and humanity itself.

item.title: Why China Can’t Win the AI-Led Industrial Revolution
item.description: History has consistently shown that industrial revolutions require free institutions and robust demand to support ongoing entrepreneurship and the commercialization of new, productivity-enhancing products and services. With its system of totalitarian party-state rule, China checks none of these boxes.

item.title: Is Crypto an Opportunity or a Threat?
item.description: Innovation should enhance economic fundamentals, not erode them. With enthusiasm for crypto remaining strong, speculative unbacked tokens and lightly regulated stablecoins must be contained before they threaten financial stability and become part of the shadow banking sector.

item.title: Trump Is Canceling the Rule of Law – and US Democracy
item.description: Not only has the second Trump administration shown an utter contempt for the rule of law, but so too have its allies in Congress and on the Supreme Court. The bedrock principle that has long defined and sustained the American democratic project is being shredded before our eyes.

item.title: Latin America’s New Birth of Democracy
item.description: The populist wave that crashed over several Latin American countries not so long ago now may be retreating. Across the region, people are waking up to their rulers’ lies and misdeeds and rediscovering the liberal, republican values that defined earlier periods of their history.

item.title: Israel Unbound
item.description: While the United States and its allies finally led a push to end the Gaza war in 2025, it is not clear how regional stability will be restored, or what shape a new regional order will assume. For the foreseeable future, the Middle East will be bracing for a prolonged conflict as Israel pursues military supremacy.

item.title: Gambling With the Dollar’s Future
item.description: While there is no immediate candidate to supplant the US dollar, ballooning US deficits, the risk of higher US inflation, and the fragmentation of global trade have complicated the picture. In this environment, US policymakers' complacency about America's "exorbitant privilege" seems dangerously unjustified.

item.title: The Year That Could Be
item.description: A decade after Brexit and Donald Trump's first election to the US presidency, states are increasingly isolated from one another, institutions are held hostage to the arbitrary will of individuals, and the rule of law seems irreversibly in decline. Yet even without cause for optimism, one can – and must – muster hope.

item.title: A New Age of Nuclear Proliferation?
item.description: Not only are major nuclear-weapon states failing to pursue arms control and disarmament; they are openly doubling down on "modernizing" and expanding their arsenals to match their increasingly bellicose rhetoric. Fragile global structures that are supposed to prevent our self-annihilation are crumbling before our eyes.

item.title: Trump and the End of American Hegemony
item.description: In 2025, Donald Trump's erratic, unlawful policies upended the postwar era of globalization and set in motion a process that will culminate in America's loss of global primacy. Not only are the sources of US economic strength being destroyed, but all other countries are de-risking from America as fast as they can.

item.title: Filling America’s Shoes
item.description: With the United States cutting aid, scrapping international agreements, and waging war on rules-based systems and arrangements that it built, questions about the future of the global order have gained new urgency. Though America may be replaceable in some areas, others may become a new Wild West.

item.title: Give Ukraine Back Its Future
item.description: There is more than a little irony in the fact that Ukrainians are bleeding and dying for Western democracy and the European Union at a time when so many are losing faith in both. But they are – and they have shown that they can win.

item.title: “Never Again,” Again
item.description: The West is facing its greatest challenge in decades. The postwar order that was shaped by the trauma of World War II and the Holocaust, and built on a foundation of political compromise, respect for other countries’ sovereignty, free markets, civil liberties, and minority protections, is now at risk of collapsing.

item.title: Asia Adrift, Asia Alone
item.description: Just as Asian democracies had to adapt to a long period of economic and geopolitical uncertainty following the American withdrawal from Vietnam 50 years ago, now they must do so again. Donald Trump's return has forced the region to pursue self-reliance and new, mutually beneficial economic arrangements.

item.title: Building Peace Together
item.description: It is all too easy for world leaders to turn away from conflicts where there is no simple solution, or crises where there is no quick fix. But in today's world, from the Middle East and Ukraine to Myanmar and Sudan, that would leave few conflicts and crises to address.

item.title: Multilateralism Is Not Dead Yet
item.description: Nationalists and populists may often speak the loudest in today's political discourse, but that does not make them representative. In fact, global polls still show a clear majority in support of international cooperation to address conflicts, poverty, climate change, and other shared challenges.

item.title: The Age of Stagflation?
item.description: From attacks on the Federal Reserve's independence to high and unpredictable tariffs, Donald Trump has pursued a slew of misguided policies that threaten to fuel stagflation, trigger financial instability, and end US dollar dominance. Emerging-market and developing economies must take action to protect themselves.
